tool.name: Gene ontology enrichment
tool.description: Find enriched GO terms from gene list
tool.command:
#if $params.method == "gsea" run_ranked_enrichment.py GSEA -p $params.perms -n $params.minset -c $params.corrpower #elif $params.method == "rpc" run_ranked_enrichment.py parent-child -s "$params.side" -m $params.rmethod #if $params.rank -r #end if #if $params.corrections -c $params.corrections #end if #elif $params.method == "pc" run_enrichment.py parent-child -m "$params.pcmethod" #if $params.corrections -c $params.corrections #end if #elif $params.method == "tt" run_enrichment.py term-for-term #if $params.corrections -c $params.corrections #end if #end if
-i ${input.file_name} -a ${assoc.file_name} -g ${go_graph.file_name} -f html tabular -o ${output.file_name} ${output2.file_name}

param.name: minset
param.label: Minimal intersection between set of genes in rank and in studied set

param.name: corrpower
param.label: How strong correlation will affect enrichment

param.name: side
param.label: from which side (highest or lowest) to start computation

param.name: rank
param.label: only the rank should be used as population

tool.help:
**Overview**
Gene Ontology tool is designed to analyse biological terms associated with groups of genes. Using information about gene associations and ontology finds which terms are enriched in provided genes, or enriched at some point of gene ranking.
-----
**Gene set methods**
* **Term-for-term**
This method tests gene enrichment in each term separately (independingly of its relation to other terms in ontology).
Parameters:
+ *multiple hypothesis testing correction*: - *Bonferroni*
- *Benjamini-Hochberg FDR*
* **Parent-Child**
This method tests gene enrichment in a term comparing to set of parents of this terms.
Parameters:
+ *multiple hypothesis testing correction*: - *Bonferroni*
- *Benjamini-Hochberg FDR*
+ *method used to compute probabilities*: - *union* - gene set associated with parents of term `t` is set of all genes associated with any of the parents of term `t`
- *intersection* - gene set associated with parents of term `t` is set of all genes associated with all of the parents of term `t`
**Ranking methods**
* **GSEA (Gene Set Enrichment Analysis)** [GSEA]_
This method checks for every gene set, if genes in the set have tendency to group on the top or bottom of ranking, or are they distributed randomly.
Parameters:
+ *Number of permutations* - # of permutations of gene ranking generated to estimate statistical significance of gene set enrichment. More permutations give better precision of p-value but can result in higher runtime.
+ *Minimal intersection* - minimal number of genes common to the set and rank to take the set into account
+ *Correlation `p`* - weight (used in exponent) of correlation score (that is the value used to rank genes) when computing enrichment score. `p=0` reduces enrichment score to Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic. `p=1` is recomended and takes into account value forming ranking.
* **Ranked Parent-Child**
This method is an adaptation of parent-child method to use on ranking. For each term it is the minimal p-value that this term got with parent-child method on gene set generated by `k` initial elements of ranking, for some `k<=n`.
Parameters:
+ *Side* - from which side (highest or lowest or both values of ranking) to start computation. This parameter determine whether gene sets are generated by initial elements from the top or bottom or both sides of ranking.
+ *multiple hypothesis testing corrections* - which corrections of p-values to be added to the result (as separate columns)
+ *only the rank should be used as population* - If set to `Yes` only genes present in the ranking are considered as gene set (other genes in annotation file are discarded).
+ *method used to compute probabilities*: - *union* - gene set associated with parents of term `t` is set of all genes associated with any of the parents of term `t`
- *intersection* - gene set associated with parents of term `t` is set of all genes associated with all of the parents of term `t`
-----
**Input**
* Genes
*For ranking methods:* tabular file with gene name and value to use as rank indicator (i.e. expression level, p-value, fold change). Two columns (c1, c2), TAB-separated::
FBgn0043467 0.4 FBgn0010339 0.84 FBgn0070057 0.2 FBgn0070052 -1
This file does not need to be sorted and may have header starting with '#'.
*For gene set methods:* File with gene names (one per line) or tabular file with gene name in 1-st column and '0' or '1' in 2-nd column -- only genes with '1'-s will be included. Example::
FBgn0043467 1 FBgn0010339 0 FBgn0070057 0 FBgn0070052 1
For this file only 2 genes (FBgn0043467, FBgn0070052) will be used.
* Annotation
Gene annotation in GAF format: http://geneontology.org/page/go-annotation-file-format-20
* Ontology
Gene Ontology in Open Biomedical Ontology (OBO format) http://geneontology.org/faq/what-obo-file-format
-----
**Output**
Gene Ontology returns HTML file with several columns:
- -ID (GO term ID with link to geneontology.org site regarding this term)
- -name
- -(only for non-ranking methods) No. genes in term
- -(only for non-ranking methods) No. genes from list
- -p-value
- -(optional) p-values after multiple hypothesis corrections
Example::
#Enrichments found using parent_child_intersection method. ID name No. genes in term No. genes from list p-value FDR correction Bonferroni correction GO:0005737 cytoplasm 11011 72 0.000112659418604 0.00698488395347 0.00698488395347 GO:0007155 cell adhesion 606 9 0.00579391522139 0.179611371863 0.359222743726 GO:0007165 signal transduction 1689 14 0.063198962127 1.0 1.0
-----
